column1: Brandagamba is the original Westron version of the Hobbits translated into English as Brandybuck.
It contains the element branda- borderland (referring to Buckland being on the eastern edge of the Shire)
column3: border-water (the early hobbitish name for the Brandywine river).

column1: The second half of the compound
column3: is a re-occurrence from the older name Zaragamba
column4: or Oldbuck in the sense of a male deer or ram.

column1: The river Branda-nîn was later jokingly altered to Bralda-hîm
column3: "only a very bold hobbit would have ventured to call the Master of Buckland braldagamba in his hearing".

column1: While "Marchbuck Family" would be a literal translation of the name
column2: it would lose the traditional connection with Brandywine
column3: apparent in the actual Brandagamba-Branda-nîn. J.R.R. Tolkien rather translated the name as "Brandybuck" in order to retain this connection.
